Educational, fun, expensive, cheap device, get warranty.I had it for over a year now and it has pros and cons.The device itself is cheap, I had to return the first one because it quickly had issues with charger port. I was gracious for amazon replacing it so I got the warranty for the second one, which I recommend because I had to exchange it again because it just suddenly would  not hold a charge. Also it will freeze semi frequently, kids always panic lol. So far a restart fixes it.Positives is that the kids really love the games they are expensive, and almost no games are included with set up. The cheapest games are 10$ and go to 25$ and they offer bundles of like 4 games for 20-30$ but never the good games are included. They have sales on major holidays so that helps save money.The device and its games really are fun and educational. They make learning easy and fun, it's a great way to distract you kids and know the content is safe.I dislike that leap pad pushes the heck out of there popular games with ads so kids are never content and always wanting more more more...I also dislike that the main learning game ''Academy'' is a yearly subscription on 40.$$$ which I bought for my 3 and 4 year old and they almost never used. Now it's expired they are 4 and 5 now and love it. I DO like that you can use the academy game on your cell phone as well as the device and it syncs your progress.I really dislike that it requires sooooo much money to get a good group of games. The description of the games on the web page are terrible and there are no refunds if you download a game you don't like.I wanted to give 3 stars because the device is cheap, I got over 200$ invested in just games and then it stops working... exhausting and disappointing.I gave it 4 stars because the kids really love it and DO get a lot out of it. I recommend buying the warranty!

Best Learning Tablet Ever!.This is one of my favorite educational toys ever. We've owned LeapPads in the past, but this thing is on a whole new level. The apps that come with it are great, but my preschooler really loves the Academy app. I was pleasantly surprised to find out that LeapFrog gave us a free 3 month trial of their Academy app with the tablet, but my little one loved it so much that I went ahead and subscribed to it for a year. (the yearly price is VERY reasonable; especially if you homeschool like us and are used to buying extremely expensive curriculum) While set-up was super easy, I skipped a few steps and could not figure out how to get back to where I accessed my 3 free months of the Academy app. I contacted CS and they replied with very detailed instructions of how to get back to the step I missed. While waiting for them to reply, I grew impatient with my kids begging to use the new LeapPad that I just did a factory reset and started over again. Took me just a few minutes to set it up and the kids even less time to figure out how to work the tablet. It seems to be very durable and I love that the stylus pen stores in the protective bumper. I wish I had 3 of these because my kids (ages 4, 6, and 8) constantly fight over this thing! They all think they're so grown up using it because it's a legit Android-based tablet and does not look like a cheap, bulky, plastic encased toy. I use it as a bargaining tool; finish your lessons and chores and you get to play on the LeapPad first. :-) Other homeschooling parents ask us all the time what curriculum they should buy for their preschoolers. I always, always, always tell them to skip the expensive curriculum when the kids are that little and get them a LeapPad or other LeapFrog toys to let them play while they learn and inspire future school success. This thing is more than perfect for that. I am removing 1 star because the shatter-safe screen is hard to view from certain angles. You need to have it positioned just right to focus on what you're viewing. This is a problem when multiple kids are trying to view the screen at the same time. Also, something is up with the camera app. No matter how we rotate the screen, the image is captured upside down. I'm sure it's an easy fix from the app developers, but it's super frustrating for my little ones who love to walk around taking pics of literally everything. Lastly, the headphone jack will not work with my little one's safe volume headphones, but it will work with my ear buds. It can get kind of annoying for us parents who have to listen to every little sound that's coming out of the tablet when the kids are playing. Overall, we all love the LeapPad Academy learning tablet and highly recommend it for educational play for all kids from about 3 to 8 years old. The product has been provided by VTech/LeapFrog free of charge so I could experience it with my family; however, the thoughts and opinions are all my own.

Wrong plug.Product okay.However the cord that it came with was American and even though it specified on the product info and I doublechecked that it would be compatible here in New Zealand it wasn’t.I was still able to charge it with a USB but I was disappointed that I couldn’t use the plug that came with it. It was part of why I purchased this leap pad
Poor Battery life.The leap pad academy is good for learning for my 4yo, but then the battery life gets shorted when used for quite some time resulting shorter playtime for my child.

Be smart about where you buy this from *updated*.Got a couple of these from this Amazon site, and felt relieved to know that there was a one year warranty that comes with it. Well, one of the tablets died; just went black and wouldn't charge or turn on again. I thought, "No problem, I'll just call LeapFrog, let them know what happened and get shipped a replacement." After a few emails back and forth, LeapFrog informed me that having bought the tablets from Amazon, they are void of the warranty. In other words, I should have bought it from Toys R Us or Walmart. My daughter really liked it, so it looks like I'll make a trip to Walmart. But I will MAKE SURE that the warranty is valid.Updated: I got a call from the toy manufacturer telling me that this particular 3rd party (Quality Products) has a connection to the Leapfrog company. Thus, there is a valid one year warranty and we received a new one just this week :)
Durable.Was a gift.. nice

On a budget tablet?.(LOOKING TO BUY??? READ UNTIL THE END)When I had first purchased the leapfrog academy within the first few days it just stopped working, it wouldn’t charge or turn on. After a few days of it being plugged in it just turned on and it’s been on ever sinceIf you’re looking for a tablet that your kids won’t break then this is for you. It’s been dropped off counters, dressers and down the stairs 🤦🏻‍♀️ and it’s still kicking.I should note that this tablet CANNOT download mainstream apps (YouTube, Nextflix, Disney Plus) but with going through the Amazon AppStore we were able to find apps that would let you access them.The battery lasts (at 100%) anywhere from 2hrs-4hrs or more if lucky with constant use. I also noticed it’s a little slow at times depending on what you’re doing, not all the time but with bigger webpages.It’s not bad for the price, but if you’re looking for a tablet with more of a “AppStore” and more mainstream functions then I suggest buying an iPad.Leapfrog games are super educational and even tho it’s not a highend tablet my sons still able to have fun and watch YouTube videos (which was the initial reason for buying)The case comes off for easy cleaning which has a sturdy stand, the speakers are loud & it also has a 3.5mm Jack for headphones.Overall it’s not bad, but it’s not great. It functions normally so if you aren’t picky and need your kids to stop taking your phone and are on a budget this is for you.

Nice learning tablet but needs improvements.It's a really nice learning tablet for kids. Not impressed.  Emailed the company but never got a reply.The screen might be shatter proof but sure gets scratches easily. A good learning tool for $8. /month. Well made. Should withstand abuse..Altho this LeapFrog LeapPad comes with a 3  month subscription and many apps already loaded, to get maximum learning value, there is an $8. per month subscription.  Not a bad price for the value.My son has been using this LeapPad quite a bit. He likes using the stylus and I find it has helped him with his numbers and letters.  He is just starting JK so it's perfect timing to reinforce what he is learning in school and what his Dad and I have been teaching him.We already know that it is durable enough for the inevitable drops - a must have with little kids. There is an ok camera on it, certainly good enough for my son.  There are parent controls and parent portals and we spent quite a bit of time setting things up.My older daughter lost interest quickly as this LeapFrog Leappad is definitely geared more towards ages 3 to 6 in my opinion.

Good learning tablet to start at early age.My 5 year old was using iPad for various learning games and videos, but he recently broke iPad. This time I did not want to give him expensive thing like iPad and LeapFrog leapPad perfectly fits the bill.It is not that expensive and made very sturdy. Tablet is covered in rubber guard case and feels well designed and sturdy. It comes with nice stylus and kick stand to keep tablet on desk. We were impressed as soon as we opened the box we were impressed with high quality hardware. However as soon as we turned the tablet ON, we were little disappointed. Screen is not as high quality as iPad and viewing angle is very poor. You need to be perfectly viewing straight. The display seems mediocre which is expected at this price point. I am not sure if LeapFrog made it in this way to protect kids eyes. My son did not mind it and did not notice much difference.With excitement, my son started exploring included games and application and in fe days, he got bored with it. Most applications are below his age and does not interest him very long. He wanted his iPad back because it was loaded with lots of learning and fun applications. You can download and buy new applications from Leapfrog store, but they seemed quite expensive. To keep interest going, I signed up for 3 months free trial for LeapFrog Academy and honestly it his hard to keep his interest going on with it. There are few reasons behind it: (1) For kids who cannot read yet, it’s not intuitive to scan through all the contents and try it out. So he needs parent support. (2) Content is not very polished yet. For example, reading the book. when you ask to read to kids, it is way too fast. (3) His familiarity with iPad and Apple Ecosystem may be pushing him back because he is not familiar with Android system.I will keep involved with him to get his interest going and see how it goes. It should be mentioned that LeaFrog Academy costs $7.99/month and can be used on any device.Overall, I thing this is great started tablet and still think that if I had a choice earlier I would have started with this rather than iPad since it is meant for kids and slowly transition him to expensive options such as iPad when he grows up.Overall, I think it is good learning tablet to start at early age.

Good tablet, requires subscription.Like most things these days, unfortunately this tablet requires a monthly subscription in only to access LeapFrog Academy. LeapFrog Academy is an online-only service that is a digital world where your child can create an only avatar and complete different levels, working themselves through a map of different lessons.For the most part, this tablet would prefer to have internet access at all times. Luckily enough, you can save up to 24 lessons by favouriting them for offline use. This tablet does have an integrated Parental Control mode that allows you to limit access to applications, or set availability of the device.Because this is used by kids, this tablet is very rugged. The screen is plastic and there is a rubber case that will protect the tablet when it is inevitably dropped. It is very hard to crack a plastic screen, just be wary that it will scratch.Overall, this is quite good value considering the integrated applications. It is disappointing to see that there is a subscription for the Academy, however I understand that it costs money to run their servers.

Good content. Hardware is sturdy but screen is awful..I like that the LeapPad is very simple to use. It comes with a whole bunch of games out of the box and is kid-proof both in terms of the content and durability. Content is locked down tightly and the bumpers are good enough to withstand moderate drops or bumps. The kickstand is pretty durable and does a good job even on carpet.The screen is quite awful and washed out but does the job for kid use... it gets pretty washed out if you want to look at the screen together though.You'll need to subscribe to the Academy to make the most of this tablet. The three month trial included is appreciated and you can make up your mind for yourself. It's a pretty reasonably priced in my opinion but the content is really geared towards younger kids.I think that if you think of this as a tablet and compare it against the Fire tablet, you'll be sorely disappointed. But if you compare this against a string of $75 playsets, you'll find that this is a terrific value.

Perfect For Preschoolers, Pricey App Store.For its price point, this is a pretty good tablet. It comes with all you need to get started, including protective bumpers and a stylus. I call them bumpers because it is definitely not a case. I haven’t tried throwing it down the stairs but I don’t think that I can trust this silicone case for rough play. The tablet slides out of the case quite easily. There is a stand on the back of the case. The stylus is attached by a short cord and slides into the side of the tablet for storage. The usb port, micro SD slot, headphone jack, power and volume buttons are all located on the top of the tablet and not covered by the case. I don’t think it’s a great idea to make the micro SD slot that easily accessible to kids, I would have hidden it in a different place.The tablet works right out of the box. It is preloaded with some apps and others can be added. I’m pretty tech savvy and I still had to play around with this tablet to really understand how to get it going. I had to sign into my leapfrog account (or sign up for one if you don’t have one) and then set the limitations for the children using the tablet. You can set up a profile for multiple children and monitor pretty much everything from screen time to what they’re looking at.My children have specific apps that they love. Netflix, youtubekids, and roblox are the most important ones. Roblox can be downloaded through the amazon app store, but netflix has to be done differently. I still cannot get youtube kids on the tablet. The amazon app store is accessible through the parent portal of the tablet. The instructions that come with the leappad are very vague and I found myself online looking for videos on how to access and download different apps. Keep in mind though, that the leapfrog approved babysitting service isn’t available for the netflix app if you should download it. Your child will have access to everything.I think the leapfrog app store is expensive, more so than others. You get a three month subscription to the leapfrog academy included with the purchase of this tablet and after that it costs eight dollars a month. It’s basically a subscription to ongoing age appropriate school lessons. If you choose not to continue with your subscription, you can still access other apps on the tablet. So no, it doesn’t render the tablet useless.The home screen is pretty interactive, and it is really easy to navigate. There is also a voice that explains things as you go. There is a camera on the front and back of the unit, pictures are good quality. The screen is okay, it’s said to be shatter resistant. You have to look at it straight on, or you can’t see what’s on it very well. It makes sharing difficult.The recommended age for this tablet is three to eight. I think its definitely more suitable for preschool and not for older kids. My older kids were over it very quickly and didn’t have much interest in the baby apps it came with (their words, not mine). The leapfrog approved content is good, but very basic so more geared towards younger. My younger kids were happy with exploring this and find it easy to play, they used the stylus a lot.Overall, I think this is a good tablet if you have a younger child and are on a budget. My children have been using ipads from the get-go and I can set a lot of the same restrictions on those with more options as far as apps go. I find the leappad extremely limited. Which is good or bad depending on who you’re purchasing it for.

Very excited grandparent.I could not be more pleased.  As a grandparent who wants to help grow and nurture little minds, Leapfrog was the answer.  We were looking for something we, his parents and I, could download apps. I was going to use an old Kindle of mine but it was fried.  I started looking at another Kindle BUT when I started reading reviews on the horrors of parental controls I became discouraged. Then a friend reminded me of Leapfrog.  OMG! I had totally forgotten about it. So I researched them, figured out the best one and we are thrilled.  Not only does it come with everything to get started BUT it comes with bonuses like, within 24 hours of use knows the child is left handed and moved everything to the other side of the screen out of his way, no settings had to be set up for that, thank you Leapfrog.  I have to add my grandson is only 20 months old. He's already working on phonics, language and writing.  The other plus so far is the limited access to WiFi.  His parents are excited about that.  So a big THANK YOU Leapfrog.

Great for toddlers first iPad!!.This leapfrog leap pad does what it should. Long lasting battery life= long lasting fun and learning. It was very easy to set up. Parent control. It's just as described. It doesn't come with headphones. Also it doesn't have Bluetooth. But I recommend it has a lot for the price. Definitely worth it for learning fun and definitely worth buying the leapfrog academy. You and your child will love it, You won't be disappointed 😍

He gets really crazy when I take the Kindle away and somehow he gets on YouTube and finds Cartoon Network Adult Swim or other weird videos. With the Leappad, he can't do that. There are some videos from some of the apps I downloaded, but most are educational. I would take away a star because the apps are kind of expensive and Leappad Academy isn't cheap either. I'm not saying it's too expensive and that it's not worth it, it is worth it, but the apps should be more affordable for people who buy the tablet. Especially individual apps. I was honestly pretty surprised at how much I had to spend for just a handful of apps. Despite this, my loathing towards the Kindle tablet prevents me from taking a star away lol. Also, I've noticed that my son isn't crazy attached to the Leappad like he is with the Kindle. I let him play with the Leappad when he wants throughout the day, and he doesn't sit on it all day. He also doesn't freak out if I take it from him to do something else. He totally melts down if I take the Kindle from him. To me, that's another big plus in favor of the Leappad. He doesn't seem obsessed or addicted to it.

Beyond this, the actual concept is nice with 2-in-1 laptop/tablet, children email writing, and songs, but there's not much here that you wouldn't find in almost any other children's toy (maybe like 30-40 permutations of songs/activities/etc) but since you can't see anything anyways, it's much more frustrating for the child than fun and you'll get alot of anger/crying with it.  Definitely DO NOT RECOMMEND.

PARENTS BE AWARE OF MUSIC MODE.I have to write this review on my laptop however I am warning all parents of the music mode touch screen. As parents know children soak things up as a sponge soaks up water. They have big imaginations and tend to emulate what they see. I am big on a child remaining as a child and not being a raunchy adult. There is a clip in which I as a parent and most parents who actually care to raise their children properly would disagree with as being child friendly. In music mode as you are touching the music keys scout will dance and one of those dances involves shaking of the rump which is very inappropriate for a 2 year old a 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 10 etc. Thats not what a child should be engaged in and its a huge violation in my opinion. Yes its a great tool to help them learn but be vigilant because if not monitored could easily introduce vulgar and inapropriate movements in your child. Not surprising considering Netflix and cuties and now people trying to force children to make adult decisions at school..... Ima leave it there...
Dissatisfied.Not what the description described

Customizable feature not on product that was shipped..The toy itself is great.However, the description of the product says that it is customizable in a way that you can connect to a computer and add the child’s name so that they can learn their own name on the leapfrog.This was one of that main reasons that I ordered it.The one that we received doesn’t have a USB connection so that feature that is advertised in the product description is not available.

Great toy, but fingers are easily caught in part that flips screen.I wanted to love this for my twins as they are always trying to type on my laptop, but they are constantly catching their fingers in the part that flips from laptop to iPad.

Kids Who Use Real Technology Will Have Zero Interest.My 4 year old sees me working on my laptop all of the time and she loves to mimic me. At 4 years old I'm not ready to buy her a laptop or even a chromebook yet. I though this would be a great way to allow her to play pretend while also learning with an interactive toy. The problem is, she had absolutely no interest in it. To be fair, she uses a Kindle Fire and has an old iPhone, which are obviously more advanced than this product. However, I thought the laptop style of it would at least pique and keep some of her interest. She literally played with it for five minutes and told me she didn't want it. Her 5 year old sister has a chromebook so she has no interest in it either. May be good for kids who are not used to modern devices but if your child is accustomed to any type of modern tablet/phone/etc. it is doubtful this product will hold their interest at all. It's difficult to use and a bit outdated.

Nothing compared to old version.Out of all the leapfrog products to buy, I would not buy this one. To be fair to the product, I must reveal most of my dissatisfaction is from comparing it to the old version of this toy. I bought the old version used, it came programmed with a name already, no big deal, had the usb to change to my little girls name, or so I thought. I plugged it into my computer and the software for this product, conveniently had been discountined. I was a little frustrated with that fact, but I saw they had made a new version and I was more than happy to spend any amount of money on it. My little girl loved the old version of this toy and I LOVED the personalization, it said your child’s name so many times, it even had emails that you could have personalized with your child’s name and 3 family members! It also had a song of your child’s name. Similar to the violet plush toy, but even more personalized. Now comes this piece of crap, you program your child’s name into it alright, once, you program it into the first letter of their name, when they press it it’ll say “that’s the first letter of your name” and spells it. It literally only spells it, it doesn’t even SAY it. Shame on you leapfrog, as a parent with a child with autism, who is constantly looking for ways to teach her to say her name, the old software/toy was going to be perfect. This “personalization” on this new toy is cheap and lazy and ridiclous.

Poor Product - 3-6mo of use.I loved this product and so did my kids.  LOVED IT!  My niece had an older version, so we got this updated one.  My niece throws hers around and it still works.  I had 2 (TWO), both of which stopped working just as the warranty expired.  The company did give us 1 to replace it, but would not replace the 2nd one.  Same issue.  3 month of use, then stops.

Engaging & Educational, But a Battery Drainer.This children's computer is a very complete, entertaining, and educational toy for kids! It offers a wide range of activities that keep children engaged while learning, which we absolutely love as parents. It's truly a fantastic interactive tool.My main point for improvement would be the battery system. It consumes a lot of batteries very quickly, which becomes quite costly and inconvenient. An upgrade to USB charging would be spectacular, making it much more practical and eco-friendly in the long run.Overall, despite the battery issue, it's a highly recommended product for its educational value and the fun it provides. Just be prepared to stock up on batteries, or hope for a USB-chargeable version in the future!

Flip Screen is a nightmare for little ones and parents alike..As a mother of two kids with a three-year age gap, I've experienced many conflicts over toys, so I've learned that for the items my kids love, buy two. After my son received the LeapFrog Laptop as a Christmas gift a few years ago, I knew I would have to buy a second one for my daughter once she reached the appropriate age. However, I was not prepared for the updated flip-top screen. While the new screen is much brighter and more precise than the old model, the new flip feature never locks in one position, meaning the screen moves during gameplay. It frustrates my kids, and I'm honestly concerned about the device's longevity with a screen that can be on the top of the device as opposed to safely stored underneath a case/shell.

Oops.But again, for $18 to distract a baby on a long road trip, it’ll do. I’ll just have to make sure he doesn’t have the game when he really needs to know his letters the RIGHT way.

For ok life kids who can know their letters.Not many games.  Just push a letter and the laptop says the letter back and screen shows an animal jumping around. Once a child is able to do this i feel it would provide minimal fun.  I was hoping for more interactive games to teach.  Exp:  game shows a letter and encouraged the child to find it, push button, then see the animal jump and hear sounds.  Good level of voice on machine.  Just not interactive or teaching

Good design, poor quality.The design of this one is great, my kid loves it. However, the screen quality is very poor and one spot is not functioning well after a few weeks. That just kills half of the fun since he can’t play the number game now.

Good, but.We like the leapfrog tablet but it appears that there are some slight improvements that could/should be made. the numbers are good until it gets to 10, which is listed as 01.the screen also doesn’t stay in one place in laptop mode, it’d be better if we could get it to not rotate at the slightest change.

So much potential hurt by usability.There are so many great things about this toy, but a few key drawbacks make it almost unusable.1. Contrast is terrible. It’s so difficult to see the images on the screen through the touch sensors. Worse, there’s no obvious use case for the touchscreen which doesn’t even seem to work. So it’s a stupid design since the kid can barely see what’s happening. The LCD lets too much of the blue light through the pixels… like watching a dark movie on a bad LCD TV.2. Volume only has two settings.

Better in tablet mode.I really like the games for my 2 year old son. The only issue is the screen didn’t stay in place when you are using it as a laptop. The screen doesn’t  lock into place in laptop mode. If you use it as a tablet, it is fine. But a toddler is going to want to switch it up

Ehhh….Nothing spectacular about this product. You can barely see the screen. Graphics are ancient. I’m a 90’s kid and nothing has changed since then. The pictures are more clear than the actual product. The screen flips around too easily. My toddler is off and on it often. Would not buy again

great design quickly outgrown.it works fine teaching abc and 123 it would have been better to do a qwerty keyboard 10/9/7 style goint 10/9/9 having the extra buttons for space and enter instead of having the space bar be enter i guess you can tell your kid has outgrown it when you start getting complaints about not being able to have a space bar to reply to the puppys messages  the k cowbell and x drum licks are phenomenal in the music area and one full octave using the numbers is great much better than a baby keyboard that only has 5 tones the 4x3 touch sensor grid is very visible so the illusion of actually having a normal touch anywhere screen is lost battery life is phenomenal 3 years on the stock heavy dutys alkalines would probably corrode before actually discharging  off/low/high is great so simple for loudness and you can go from low to high or high to low without it resettingif you save the twisting locking tabs from the box you can affix it to a play pen wall the handle seems redundant it has handgrips on the back and using the handle can allow the screen frame to flop openthe screen frame auto flipping seems almost magical

No querty.This computer is great. It’s durable and fun. However, the keys come in alphabet order and not querty. I understand the logic behind alphabet order, but all adult keyboards are querty and imo, it does a disservice to a child to not have it designed the way a real computer is.

Laptop screen keeps flipping.Great idea for babies who want to be big! Very responsive touch screen and full keyboard. BUT as others have mentioned, the screen keeps flipping in laptop mode. I had to add a piece of Velcro and ribbon to keep this from happening and still be used for both the tablet and laptop feature.

Reset spring for screen to flip properly.We are enjoying this toy. Was bummed when the screen wouldn’t stay put in laptop mode. Saw a video online that showed how to remove the 5 screws on the front and back of the screen and, with the screen facing upwards in tablet mode, reset the springs, replace the white cover and screw all the screws back in. This allows the screen to flip on its own and set itself in place when the toy is opened to laptop mode or tablet mode.Was worth the discounted price given I had to fix it upon receipt. Our child enjoys playing with this toy and I’d recommend it to children that enjoy letters and numbers. The touchscreen is pretty responsive and works well.

Fun little learning laptop for kids!.My kid really loves this laptop/tablet toy. The screen gets pretty bright, so it's best not to use it in the dark for too long, but it also means that it can be used while it's bright outside and they can still see it fine. The screen is decently sized, it's fine for what it's trying to teach kids, and it's pixelated screen graphics also have a good refresh rate. It's nice that it will say the letters when pressed, and in one of the modes it will also show an animal on screen, say what kind of animal it is, and play a sound. This is good for learning the letters and about learning different animals. The touchscreen aspect isn't used a lot, but for the couple games it has where you're meant to interact with something on the screen it's used well. There's some more "advanced" learning too, like where it asks to find a specific letter which is also nice to see. We like that it has 2 volume modes, however do note that it does not have a mute mode. I think the learning content on this is nice, and it's a good way to introduce younger kids to the alphabet in an engaging way.

Highly recommend.This little laptop has been such a great educational toy. My two year old sings her ABC's and counts to 20 thanks to this thing. It's great. She loves the different games available as well. It's easy for her to operate and small enough that she can move it around with ease. It is also super easy to clean, as we've had to clean crayon off the screen already. The screen wasbt damaged from the drawing or the cleaning either.

Engaging for a busy two year old! 10/10 recommend.This toddler learning laptop / tablet has been such a fun and educational toy for my 2 year old! The size is perfect for small hands, and it’s lightweight enough for my toddler to carry around on their own. The buttons are colorful, engaging, and easy to press, and the sounds/music are upbeat without being too loud or annoying for parents. I love that it introduces letters, numbers, and fun phrases in a way that keeps my child entertained while learning. It feels sturdy and well-made, which is a huge plus since toddlers can be a little rough with their toys. Overall, it’s the perfect mix of playful and educational—my toddler feels like they have their own “real” laptop, and I feel great knowing they’re learning while playing. Highly recommend for any parent looking for an engaging educational toy!

My favorite kids toy by far!.This little laptop is a life saver! My son is obsessed with my laptop but since Ive gotten this one he does not touch mine. I can hear him repeat the sounds that scout is making and he is 21 months old with very little words. He stays entertained for a good while. We do not do a lot of TV and i prefer him not to be looking at a phone or iPad or any other electronic, so this feels a little safer, the screen isn't as bright and looks similar to some of the toys we had as kids. It flips around as an "iPad" and the screen is actually touch screen so that is pretty cool as well. The size of this is small enough to put in his little bag and he carries it around everywhere. The price on this is incredible and it will probably be my new gifts for all my friends with kids!
